awd_titl_txt: Ab Initio Calculation of Accurate Molecular Wave Functions
awd_abstract_narration: This project to develop geminal-based methods in molecular electronic   structure theory is supported jointly by the NSF Theoretical and   Computational Chemistry Program and the the Advanced Scientific Computing   Division.   Methods will be developed for the computation of accurate, ab   initio, small molecule, electronic wavefunctions using contracted   Gaussian geminals (predetermined linear combinations of   explicitly-correlated, two-particle, Gaussian basis functions).  Geminal   parameters for molecules will be extracted from optimized atomic   wavefunctions.  Scalable algorithms will be developed for implementation   on parallel computers.    The quantum mechanical electronic wavefunction is a mathematical function   of the spatial and spin coordinates of all the electrons in the atom or   molecule.  These many-body  functions are traditionally expressed in   terms of orbitals, i.e. functions of the coordinates of a single   electron.  Orbital-based concepts and computational methods play a   central role in modern chemical theory, but there is a practical limit to   the accuracy attainable in orbital-based computations using existing   supercomputers.  The goal of this project is to develop improved   computational methods using geminals (explicit functions of the   coordinates of a pair of electrons) rather than orbitals.  If successful,   this will significantly increase the accuracy of theoretical predictions   of gas phase reaction rates such as those required for improved computer   models of the earth's atmosphere.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
